Award.AwardTitle: Using the Tools of Conservation Paleobiology to Assess the Impact of the Engineered Spring-Flood of the Colorado River
Award.AbstractNarration:
Using the Tools of Conservation Paleobiology to Assess the Impact of the Engineered Spring-Flood of the Colorado River
By
Gregory P. Dietl, Paleontological Research Institute, EAR-1420978

ABSTRACT
The over allocation of the Colorado River's water has led to the ecological devastation of its delta and lowermost channel. The Colorado River annually delivered over fifteen million acre-feet (~1.85x1010 m3) of water to its delta but in recent years that number has been zero. In 2012, via a bi-national agreement known as Minute 319, environmental pulse flows equal to approximately 1% of the natural annual river discharge were negotiated by the United States and Mexico to be released over a five-year trial period. While this engineered environmental flow has the potential to be a restoration success story, there is a crucial gap in our knowledge: no studies on the ecology of the molluscan community in the lowermost channel of the river are available to provide a benchmark for evaluating the success of this restoration effort. The first pulse will be released in the early spring of 2014, providing a small window in which to establish a baseline for current conditions. This proposal thus seeks support to use a relatively simple community-based approach - comparison of molluscan living and time-averaged death assemblages - developed by conservation paleobiologists to establish a baseline. The samples collected will provide a unique perspective on the composition of the pre-pulse-flow community that is not available from any other source, which will allow the asking of future questions about the success of the pulse flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The over-allocation of the Colorado River’s water has led to downstream ecological change in its estuary. The Colorado River annually delivered over fifteen million acre-feet of water to its estuary but in recent years that number has been zero. In 2012, via a bi-national agreement known as Minute 319, environmental pulse flows equal to approximately 1% of the natural annual river discharge were negotiated by the United States and Mexico to be released over a five-year trial period. This unprecedented landscape-scale experiment demands, and will continue to demand, assessment of its effects. There is a crucial gap, however, in our knowledge: no studies on the ecology of the molluscan community in the estuary  are available to provide a baseline for evaluating the success of this restoration effort. In this study, we quantified differences in the structure of the bivalve community living in the Colorado River estuary immediately prior to the release of the Minute 319 pulse flows and two geohistorical baselines, the accumulated dead shells on the tidal flat and an older accumulation – known to pre-date dam construction on the river – in nearby shell-rich beach deposits called cheniers.

Analysis of more than 12,000 live and dead bivalve specimens distributed among 18 species collected from the tidal flat and cheniers on Isla Montague – an island at the mouth of the Colorado River – indicated that the pre-dam bivalve community was dominated by Mulinia modesta and was characterized by low species richness and evenness. The shift in these metrics reflects an environmental change in the estuary from brackish to full marine conditions after damming and water diversions reduced freshwater flow to the estuary during the twentieth century. These pre-pulse flow baseline data can be used to assess the effectiveness of the Minute 319 restoration efforts. If the environmental flows stimulated a response in the bivalve community in the estuary, metric values for evenness and richness are expected to decrease and become more similar to those we found for the pre-dam chenier assemblage.

Fieldwork in the Colorado River estuary was also documented to develop a “virtual fieldwork experience” (VFE) to solve the mystery of chenier formation, as a lens through which to learn about interactions among fluvial and tidal processes, sedimentation, erosion, human activities, such as damming of the Colorado River, and coastal ecology. The VFE is primarily built in the online presentation software Prezi, in which we embedded photographs, video, and question sets across a zoomable canvas. Students can move through investigation of the process of chenier investigation either linearly, using a series of question sets, or in their own directions. The VFE activity is linked to from a website that includes an overview of how to use and make VFEs, and an introduction to the Colorado River estuary VFE. The VFE is complemented by a student worksheet with questions and a teacher version of the worksheet with introduction, connections to Next Generation Science Standards, and suggested answers to the problems sets. At the end of the teacher worksheet we invite teachers to take an online survey (a Google form) to provide feedback on improving future versions of the VFE.
